entry.et: Middle English, from Latin separatus, past participle of separare, from se- apart + parare to prepare, procure secede, pare

def.dt: :to make a distinction between :discriminate distinguish separate religion from magic
:to disperse in space or time :scatter widely separated homesteads
:to set aside for a special purpose :choose dedicate
:to sever contractual relations with :discharge was separated from the army
:to isolate from a mixture :extract separate cream from milk
:to dislocate (as a shoulder) especially in sports
:to cease to live together as a married couple
:to become isolated from a mixture the crystals separated out

entry.pt: separate part divide sever sunder divorce mean to become or cause to become disunited or disjointed. separate may imply any of several causes such as dispersion, removal of one from others, or presence of an intervening thing separated her personal life from her career. part implies the separating of things or persons in close union or association vowed never to part. divide implies separating into pieces or sections by cutting or breaking civil war divided the nation. sever implies violence especially in the removal of a part or member a severed limb. sunder suggests violent rending or wrenching apart a city sundered by racial conflict. divorce implies separating two things that commonly interact and belong together cannot divorce scientific research from moral responsibility.

def.dt: :estranged from a parent body separate churches
:dissimilar in nature or identity consulted five separate authorities
:an article of dress designed to be worn interchangeably with others to form various costume combinations usually used in plural
